Andrew Wood update: Authorities in Denmark have advised people in the country to avoid using public transport where possible in a measure aimed at limiting the spread of coronavirus. Guidelines have also been provided to people taking buses, trains and metros in the country. A specific area in which the public has been encouraged to change its behaviour to hinder coronavirus spread is public transport. In a press statement, the Ministry of Transport and Housing encouraged avoiding peak periods if possible, to reduce crowds. Recommendation on March 11 that all employees in non-critical functions should be sent home to work from home. AW Update from Lucy Goodfellow original: “Here are the four measures announced on Thursday: The release of the so-called 'countercyclical capital buffer' banks have been required to keep on their books since the 2007 financial crisis. This will provide them an extra 200bn Danish kroner in liquidity, which they can either use to lend to businesses or to withstand losses on existing loans. Two new loan guarantee schemes, one for large companies and one for small and medium enterprises (SMEs). The government will guarantee 70 percent of the value of any new bank loans given to SMEs who have seen operating profits fall by more than 50 percent. This could back up to 4.8bn kroner in new loans. It will guarantee 70 percent of the value of new loans to large companies who can demonstrate a fall in turnover over more than 50 percent. This could back 2.7bn kroner in new loans. Employers from now on be completely reimbursed by the government from the first day that an employee becomes ill or enters quarantine due to coronavirus, rather than having to themselves absorb the bill for the few days. Employment legislation is being relaxed to allow companies to reduce employees hours temporarily, with the employees incomes then supplemented by unemployment benefit. The Ministry of Employment hopes that this will prevent employees from being laid off.” (source: https://www.thelocal.dk/20200313/denmark-moves-to-protect-economy-from-coronavirus-impact) 4.8bn kr + 2.7bn kr = 7.5bn kr, which is $1,112,519,985.92 on 13.03.20 http://web.archive.org/web/20200415142429/https://www.x-rates.com/historical/?from=USD&amount=1&date=2020-03-13

Effective 12:00 p.m. on March 14 the government of Denmark closed its borders to all but Danish citizens, individuals with Danish work or residency permits, and those the Danish government determines have a critical purpose of travel (eg, someone commissioned to provide goods or services in Denmark).  The closures will be in effect until April 13.    (source: https://politi.dk/coronavirus-i-danmark/in-english/minstry-of-justice-12-03-2020)

Measures were first introduced by the March 17th guidelines issued by  the Board of Health, ’Håndtering af COVID-19: Besøg på institutioner hvor personer fra  risikogrupper bor eller har langvarigt ophold’. These recommended that family members and  friends should not visit nursing homes (or hospitals) unless strictly necessary, for instance if the  person was terminally ill. The individual institution should ensure that the visit could be  conducted in a safe manner, for instance by ensuring that it was only a brief visit, that visitors  did not sit in common areas and that they did not have physical contact or use common  facilities. The institution was required to inform visitors about the risk of spreading the disease  and encouraging them to avoid visiting, through posters (see poster below with the message  ‘You best protect your loved ones by not visiting them’) and personal instruction. If family  members had symptoms, they were not allowed to visit. Instead, it was recommended to stay  in contact over the telephone, video or mail.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200715194521/https://ltccovid.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/The-COVID-19-Long-Term-Care-situation-in-Denmark-29-May-2020-1.pdf

Starting on 18 March at 10:00 AM, a number of further restrictions were introduced: it became illegal to assemble more than ten people in public, all shopping centres and stores with close contact such as hairdressers and nightclubs must be closed, restaurants can only serve take-away, and other businesses must ensure that there is enough space between customers. Unlike previous restrictions on the number of people allowed to assemble, the new restrictions are not merely a recommendation, and breaking the new restrictions is associated with fines of DKK1500.    (source: https://www.dr.dk/nyheder/politik/faa-overblikket-over-de-nye-corona-tiltag-se-hvad-du-ikke-maa-fra-i-dag-klokken-10)

A formal ban of visiting was introduced on April 6th ’Besøgsrestriktioner på plejehjem m.v. og  sygehuse’. The Board for Patient Safety enforced that the municipalities introduced restrictions  preventing visitors in the nursing homes. This included visits inside the institution, and in  common areas as well as the apartments or rooms. It could also include outdoor areas if  necessary but this was a decision to be taken by the Municipal Board. In critical cases, visits  could be allowed. This included terminal patients or persons with dementia who lack the ability  to understand the special situation and the need for restrictions. Again, it was a decision of the  Municipal Board to determine whether visits were allowed in these cases.

Full reopening of the retail sector (11 May 2020)  The entire retail sector, including shopping centres, can reopen if they follow the guidelines agreed by the sector partnership: Guidelines for a careful layout of shopping-goods shops and other retail shops in light of the outbreak of COVID-19.    Restaurants and cafes will slowly come to life again (18 May 2020)  Restaurants, cafes and similar establishments can start serving food and drinks if they follow specific guidelines on opening hours, physical distancing, etc.  Private sector employees working from home  It has been accepted that a large number of private sector employees will again report for work as usual at their workplaces.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200521225925/https://politi.dk/en/coronavirus-in-denmark/controlled-reopening-of-denmark

Public transport  In the recent weeks of partial lockdown of the Danish society, the number of passengers using public transport has been down by more than 80 per cent. The current timetables for busses, the light rail, trains and the metro have therefore been downscaled.         A consequence of the controlled reopening of society is that the number of passengers will increase. To avoid excessive passenger density, a considerable upscaling of public transport has been made as from Tuesday, 14 April 2020 in Metropolitan Copenhagen in particular. The upscaling will involve more departures and longer trains. Users, schools and workplaces must also contribute to an even use of public transport through flexible planning. Moreover, the increased cleaning frequency on common contact surfaces in public transport means and at stations will remain at the same high level.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200521225925/https://politi.dk/en/coronavirus-in-denmark/controlled-reopening-of-denmark

Temporary border control and entry restrictions  Temporary border control and entry restrictions came into effect at all Danish borders on 14 March 2020. The period of border checks, which do not usually include freight transports, has been extended until further notice.         Stricter travel advice from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs  The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has continuously changed its travel advice, but froze the breakdown of the world into red and orange areas as at 17 March 2020. Danish citizens returning from abroad are strongly urged to isolate themselves at home for two weeks and Danish citizens are advised against all but essential travel abroad at least until 1 June 2020.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200521225925/https://politi.dk/en/coronavirus-in-denmark/controlled-reopening-of-denmark

The political parties note that the Government will implement the testing strategy in the weeks ahead and will focus on efficient tracking and tracing of outbreaks of the novel coronavirus among close contacts and home isolation of people with COVID-19.  The authorities are currently working on upscaling the capacity for testing for the novel coronavirus to perform more offensive testing in connection with the upcoming controlled reopening of the Danish society. The tests to be performed during the initial testing phase are diagnostic tests, but concurrent efforts will be made to try out and introduce so-called immune tests, which can detect COVID-19 antibodies.  In addition to ensuring the relevant treatment of individuals, the testing scheme is also intended partly to contain the disease by diagnosing individuals for the purpose of self-isolation and by curbing the spread of the disease through early detection and partly to monitor the prevalence of the disease in society.  An offensive testing strategy comprising the testing of both a cohort of healthcare staff and a cohort of the general population, the tracking and tracing of outbreaks of coronavirus and home isolation of people with coronavirus. A representative portion of the population will be tested at regular intervals based on a clear plan.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200521225925/https://politi.dk/en/coronavirus-in-denmark/controlled-reopening-of-denmark

May 12: The Danish Health Authority published an updated strategy for testing and contact tracing. In contrast to previous plans on this regard, it will now be the responsibility of public authorities to assist in tracking and contacting close contacts to persons tested positive for COVID-19. Close contacts will be offered to be tested on day 4 and day 6 of the initial contact. Close contacts will be urged to enter into self-isolation until they have received a negative result of the testing. The government will provide capacity for those that are unable to self-isolate at home, e.g. in hotels  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503195721/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/denmark/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5+Testing&Type=Section

May 15: A majority of the parliament agreed to develop an app in a public-private partnership. The app will track citizens who voluntarily decide to use the app, and if a citizen using the app is diagnosed with COVID-19, all citizens who have been close to the patient will be informed that they may have been exposed to COVID-19, but the identity of the patient will not be revealed to them.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503195721/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/denmark/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5+Testing&Type=Section

Pupils in the sixth to tenth grades back to school (18 May 2020)  Older children are allowed back to school. Local authorities and schools are given flexibility to make detailed practical plans in compliance with the health protection guidelines to be agreed by the sector partnership. This also applies to after-school clubs.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200518234406/https://politi.dk/en/coronavirus-in-denmark/latest-news-and-hotlines/agreement-on-phase-two-of-the-controlled-reopening

As of May 18th the following have re-opened in Denmark:  -Restaurants and cafés may  -Libraries, churches and religious communities   - Popular outdoors sports and professional sport without spectators are also allowed.  -Safari parks, where guests drive around in cars, are allowed to open. May 18: In order to increase testing of the population, all citizens may get tested (in “the societal track”) without a referral – a citizen who wants to get tested for COVID-19 may make a reservation on a website: https://www.coronaprover.dk/Account/NemIdLogin?RequestPath=%2F    This has been fully implemented by May 25 based on a daily testing capacity up to 50,000 tests. Citizens with symptoms must still call their GP to be referred to a test at a hospital (“the health care track”) (http://sum.dk/Aktuelt/Nyheder/Coronavirus/2020/Maj/Alle-borgere-faar-mulighed-for-at-blive-testet-for-COVID-19.aspx).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503192228/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/denmark/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5+Testing&Type=Section

There are no inter-city or inter-regional restrictions on internal movement in Denmark. From May 25 2020, people with a permanent residence in one of the five Nordic countries (Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Sweden) or Germany will be allowed to re-enter Denmark if they fall into the following categories:  -Business trips to and from Denmark if they are carried out responsibly in terms of health, may be resumed if the applicable precautionary measures are followed. Business trips must comply with industry-specific security precautions.  -People who own a summer house in Denmark  -Persons who have a relationship with a person living in Denmark or who are engaged to a person living in Denmark  -People who have grandparents in Denmark  Except for the above, general family visits, tourism trips, business trips, study trips or similar are not grounds for entry into Denmark that are worthy of recognition.     http://web.archive.org/web/20200531181446/https://www.visitdenmark.com/denmark/travel-essentials/coronavirus    http://web.archive.org/web/20200531182118/https://www.thelocal.dk/20200521/museums-high-schools-and-borders-next-reopening-plans-announced

From May 27 2020, high schools, adult education and language centres can reopen. This means the oldest school children, from ages 16, can return to school before the summer holiday. Evening, music and cultural schools, scouts, as well as outdoor amusement parks and summer activities for children and young people can also reopen.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200531182118/https://www.thelocal.dk/20200521/museums-high-schools-and-borders-next-reopening-plans-announced  In Danish (government press release):   http://web.archive.org/web/20200531182702/https://www.regeringen.dk/nyheder/2020/aftale-om-yderligere-genaabning-i-fase-2/

The government announced on 29 May that they are supporting the welfare of the municipalities by covering the extra costs this year resulting from the corona epidemic and will lift the municipal services framework in 2021. Next year, the facility ceiling will be raised extraordinarily to DKK 21.6 billion. This gives the municipalities the opportunity to increase investments and thus support employment.  Overview of main elements of the agreement for Danish regions:  -The agreement will compensate the regions for their preliminary costs for handling COVID-19. This will ensure that the regions' expenditure does not displace other citizen welfare.  -The region's financial framework in the health sector is lifted by just over DKK 1.3 billion. DKK 2021 in 2021.  -The agreement assumes a regional technology contribution of DKK 400 million. DKK 2021, which the regions release, and which are prioritized to finance increased processing capacity.  -An extraordinary increase in the gross ceiling on construction costs (20 billion) by 2021 has been agreed. DKK to support activity and employment. This means a total level of ceilinged investments of DKK 3.5 billion. DKK 2021 in 2021, in addition to expected investments in quality fund construction of DKK 4 billion. DKK 2021 in 2021, corresponding to the realized level in recent years.  -With a view to promoting public-private cooperation, a loan and deposit exemption pool of DKK 400 million will be established. DKK 2021 in 2021.  - The regions must reduce their costs for external consultants by DKK 100 million. DKK 2021 annually from 2021.  Overview of main elements of the agreement for Danish municipalities:  -Total welfare priority for a total of 2.3 billion kroner. DKK 2021 in 2021.  - The priority consists of a lift of the municipal service framework of DKK 1.5 billion. DKK 0.5 billion, reduced consumption by external consultants of DKK 0.5 billion. and a welfare priority of DKK 0.25 billion. kr.  -The municipal level in 2021 will be raised to DKK 21.6 billion. It ensures good opportunities to invest in the physical framework of welfare and provides opportunities to support employment.  -The municipalities are compensated for the already calculated extra and minor costs for handling COVID-19 for a total of 2.6 billion. The government and Local Government Denmark (KL) agree that there may be a need to revise the economy later in 2020, when there is more clarity on the future.    In Danish:  http://web.archive.org/web/20200531191327/https://www.regeringen.dk/nyheder/2020/kommuner-og-regioner-faar-daekket-coronaudgifter/  http://web.archive.org/web/20200531191814/https://fm.dk/nyheder/nyhedsarkiv/2020/maj/oekonomiaftale-med-kl-daekker-coronaregning-og-kan-sparke-gang-i-vaeksten/  http://web.archive.org/web/20200531192113/https://fm.dk/nyheder/nyhedsarkiv/2020/maj/oekonomiaftale-med-danske-regioner-daekker-coronaregning-i-2020-og-giver-1-3-mia-mere-til-velfaerd-i-2021/

Indoor sports activities were also re-opened including swimming pools  and fitness centres.   http://web.archive.org/web/20200610190938/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-denmark/denmark-to-allow-public-gatherings-of-200-in-august-idUSKBN23F0FI  http://web.archive.org/web/20200610190518/https://kum.dk/nyheder-og-presse/pressemeddelelser/nyheder/nu-genaabner-endnu-mere-idraet-og-foreningsliv/1/1/  http://web.archive.org/web/20200618202300/https://mino.dk/covid19/english/

Further reopening is taking place.    Phase 3 on June 8 will see the reopening of:   Museums, theatres, art galleries, cinemas, aquariums   Outdoor amusement parks   Zoos and botanical gardens   Summer activities for children and young people   Public sector organisations facing bottle necks   Full opening of public research activities   Adult education sectors for the unemployed  Language schools   Indoor sports and other group activities (such as evening classes)   https://web.archive.org/web/20210503170456/https://www.thelocal.dk/20200508/denmark-to-lift-most-remaining-restrictions-in-early-june/    Events with up to 50 people allowed from 8 June  As of 8 June, events with up to 50 participants are again allowed. Larger events will continue to be banned for now. The ban does not hinder that 50 or more people can be in a supermarket, in an airport or in a train station at the same time or that political meetings and demonstration can take place.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503170159/https://www.visitdenmark.com/press/latest-news/coronavirus-information-denmark    Danish museums, amusement parks and cinemas will be allowed to reopen from June 8, the government said on Friday, after it struck a deal with parliament on how restrictions to curb the spread of COVID-19 could be eased further. In the third phase of its reopening plan, Denmark will also increase the maximum number of people allowed to meet in public to between 30 and 50, up from a 10-person limit, it said.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503165900/https://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2020/05/08/denmark-to-ease-coronavirus-restrictions-further-from-june-8.html

Contact tracking is now being intensified with the establishment of Corona Tracking at the Danish Agency for Patient Safety.    All COVID-19 positives now receive help in contact tracking of close contacts  So far, it has been possible to get advice and help from the Joint Authority Hotline. But now Corona Detection in the Danish Agency for Patient Safety will make a more outreach effort to COVID-19-positive people to offer help with contact tracing of close contacts.    "Instead of waiting for the COVID-19-positive to contact us, we will now contact anyone who is tested positive for COVID-19. Having to contact people with whom you have been in close contact can Therefore, our new contact tracing unit will offer a more active help to that task. Hopefully this means that we can break the chains of infection even earlier and keep the epidemic down, because there is a systematization and unification of the entire contact tracing part." says Anette Lykke Petri, Acting Director of the Danish Agency for Patient Safety    The contact tracking unit is staffed by healthcare professionals  Corona detection in the Danish Agency for Patient Safety will be staffed with healthcare professionals with relevant competencies, eg people who have experience with infection detection from the containment phase. Healthcare professionals will contact people who have tested positive for COVID-19 to offer advice and assistance.    It is voluntary to accept the offer of advice or assistance with contact tracing. But it is of great social significance that as many as possible accept the help, i.a. because it is important that the close contacts are tested on the correct days in relation to when they were exposed to infection and that test references are correct.    However, no concrete evidence of the effectiveness of the tracing service "on the ground" - so still recorded as a 1.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503193702/https://stps.dk/da/nyheder/2020/nu-intensiveres-kontaktopsporingen-af-naere-kontakter-til-covid-19-positive/

Starting June 15th, Denmark reopened its borders to visitors from Norway, Iceland, and Germany. Restrictions apply to visitors from these countries including a minimum of 6 nights in the country is required in order to enter – overnight stays are not allowed in Copenhagen. Sample screening tests for COVID-19 will be conducted at the borders.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200618202300/https://mino.dk/covid19/english/

The app agreed upon on May 15 was presented: “Smitte|stop” (Infection|stop’). If a citizen downloads the app on his/her mobile phone, the app registers which phones the citizen is in close contact with, and if the citizen is diagnosed with COVID-19 and registers this finding in the app, the other users of the app, who have been close to the citizen, will receive a warning that they may have been exposed to COVID-19 (specifically: if a device has been closer than one meter to the device belonging to the citizen diagnosed with COVID-19 for more than 15 minutes less than two weeks before the diagnosis, the owner of the device will receive a warning). The other citizens will not be informed which person was infected, and the information that a citizen was infected will be automatically validated by the national patient registry, before the other citizens receive the warning. Due to privacy and data protection concerns, there is no centralized storage of data from the app.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503195721/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/denmark/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5+Testing&Type=Section

Danish government announced a further opening of its borders towards countries in the EU/Schengen/UK areas with effect as of 27 June 2020. The Danish Health Authority now recommends using face masks in certain special situations, bringing the policy in Denmark closer to that of other European countries such as France and Germany.  According to its new advice to those who have tested positive, those in close contact with someone who has tested positive, and those with symptoms, the authority recommends people use face masks if they are forced to leave self-isolation.      "Use a face mask if you break self-isolation to go out to take a test," the leaflets read, before linking to a guide for correctly using masks.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201014111848/https://www.thelocal.dk/20200709/danish-health-agency-recommends-face-masks

Testing remains widely available in Denmark, and anyone can make an appointment, even with no symptoms.   If you have symptoms If you have symptoms of COVID-19, get tested at one of the hospital's test clinics. You must contact your doctor to be referred for testing. The doctor will assess whether you should be examined further and whether you should be referred for testing. If your doctor refers you for a test, you must be tested at one of the hospitals' test clinics and must book an appointment at coronaprover.dk.   If you have no symptoms If you do not have symptoms of COVID-19, but have been summoned for a test or for other reasons want to be tested, you must be tested at one of Testcenter Denmark's test stations. All Danes 12 years or older and residing in Denmark as well as incoming workers with administrative CPR no. has the opportunity to book time for a virus test in Testcenter Denmark. You may also have been called in for a test if, for example, you have been in contact with someone who is infected, due to your work or as part of a population survey. You book your own time for testing at one of Testcenter Denmark's test stations at coronaprover.dk. if you have NemID. Otherwise, you can call the region you are testing in.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200716185730/https://www.coronaprover.dk/Account/NemIdLogin http://web.archive.org/web/20200807213615/https://www.coronaprover.dk/Account/WhoCanBookTime

Discotheques, nightclubs and the like are still closed. All restaurants, cafes, bars etc. are still open however have to close at midnight. Since 18 May, there has been a ban on staying open from midnight to 5 am, except for takeaway food and drinks and to a certain extent also private parties. The ban is scheduled to apply until at least 1 September 2020.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200727200755/https://politi.dk/en/coronavirus-in-denmark/extension-of-measures-during-the-covid19-outbreak-in-denmark https://web.archive.org/web/20210503220219/https://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2020/05/08/denmark-to-ease-coronavirus-restrictions-further-from-june-8.html https://web.archive.org/web/20200524011920mp_/https://politi.dk/en/-/media/mediefiler/corona/pdf-sider/controlled-reopening-of-denmark.pdf?la=en&hash=6BCEA7B32D97D12FFE6F807EADD77E64E37DE3B4

The rules remain unchanged. Public events can take place however with a maximum of 500 people if they are mainly seated, and a maximum of 100 people gathering in all other cases (whether in a private or public setting). Premises for sports and recreational activities, including gambling arcades, water parks, play areas, public swimming pools and fitness centres, have been open since 8 June 2020. However, events, activities etc. with more than 100 participants gathering simultaneously at the same location are still banned unless the participants are mainly seated. The ban on gatherings does not extend to professional sports, including the top two male football leagues, the top female football league, the top male handball league, the top female handball league, the top male ice hockey league, the top badminton league, harness races and gallop races at the nine commercial horse racing tracks with licenced drivers and riders as well as other professional branches of sports in which most athletes make a living as athletes. Nor does the ban extend to athletes at senior international level whose primary source of income is their athlete's salary, or who belong to one of the athlete categories of Team Denmark or have been nominated or selected for the Olympic/Paralympic Games.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200727200755/https://politi.dk/en/coronavirus-in-denmark/extension-of-measures-during-the-covid19-outbreak-in-denmark

The restriction on gatherings of more than 100 people (expanded from 50 to 100 on July 8th) remains in place until August 8th when it is scheduled to increase to 200 people. This ban applies to both indoor and outdoor gatherings, and it applies to both public and private events etc. The ban on gatherings of more than 100 people gathered simultaneously at the same location does not apply to private homes and adjacent gardens where 500 people are allowed to gather. However, this exemption to the ban on gatherings does not apply to courtyards and the like which are at the disposal of residents from a large number of homes. The ban on gatherings of more than 100 people gathered at simultaneously the same location does not apply to premises, locations, events, activities etc. at which customers, visitors or participants are mainly seated. Music venues with a seated audience can stay open. However, a maximum of 500 people can be allowed access to the music venue.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200727200755/https://politi.dk/en/coronavirus-in-denmark/extension-of-measures-during-the-covid19-outbreak-in-denmark

The Danish Ministry of Transport and Housing issued a press release that as of 22 August 2020, all passengers aged 12 or more must wear face masks or shields on all means of public transport, on ferries and in taxis. Customer-facing staff must also wear face masks or shields.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200826184752/https://politi.dk/en/-/media/mediefiler/corona/genaabning/face-masks-or-shields-required-on-all-forms-of-public-transport-from-22-august-2020.pdf?la=en&hash=3438F39C3B8F72E5FA2BE5BC514308FF091C910C

The Danish Ministry of Transport and Housing issued a press release that as of 22 August 2020, all passengers aged 12 or more must wear face masks or shields on all means of public transport, on ferries and in taxis. Customer-facing staff must also wear face masks or shields.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200826184752/https://politi.dk/en/-/media/mediefiler/corona/genaabning/face-masks-or-shields-required-on-all-forms-of-public-transport-from-22-august-2020.pdf?la=en&hash=3438F39C3B8F72E5FA2BE5BC514308FF091C910C

The government and the Liberal Party, the Radical Left, the Socialist People's Party, the Conservatives and the Alternative have entered into an agreement to phase out aid packages and instead target efforts to those parts of business, culture and sports that are affected by restrictions with a ban on keeping  assembly bans, border closures and travel restrictions until 31 October 2020. The new agreement allocates DKK 100 million to expand the existing help packages for culture, sports and community associations, which is administered by DIF, DGI, Firmaidrætten and DUF.      http://web.archive.org/web/20200831162745/https://www.regeringen.dk/nyheder/2020/ny-politisk-aftale-skal-sikre-restriktionsramte-virksomheder-kulturliv-og-idraet/

As of September 1 2020: Employers in Denmark can apply to send staff home for 20-50 percent of their normal working hours, with wages compensated by the government, under a new scheme to help firms affected by the coronavirus crisis. By ‘workload sharing’, the scheme enables companies to share available work between employees when there is less to do than under normal circumstances. That allows, say, two employees to be retained even though operations are only at 50 percent of capacity, because both employees can be sent home 50 percent of the time and receive full pay, with the government scheme covering costs. The new scheme replaces a former wage compensation scheme which expired at the end of August. The scheme is additional to other schemes in place to support individuals and companies during the covid-19 period.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200914191430/https://www.thelocal.dk/20200901/part-time-pay-for-corona-hit-companies-heres-how-denmarks-new-wage-scheme-works

No change in policy. All schools and universities are open in Denmark following the summer holidays however special covid-19 rules apply. For universities these include blending online and in-person classes as much as possible, restricted number of persons per classroom (generally max 25-30 per classroom), social distancing (1 meter between students also in the classroom), staggering of classes playing outside in the 'free time' in the school break, preferably keeping the same group of children together for classes and not mixing, plus regularly cleaning at all times. Face masks are not required.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200906120805/https://studies.ku.dk/masters/covid-19-virus/  http://web.archive.org/web/20200906121716/https://www.uvm.dk/aktuelt/i-fokus/information-til-uddannelsesinstitutioner-om-coronavirus-covid-19/lovgivning-og-retningslinjer  http://web.archive.org/web/20200906122136/https://www.retsinformation.dk/eli/lta/2020/1228

No major change in policy. The government announced on September 7 2020 that due to an increase in Covid-19 cases in 18 municipalities (including Copenhagen and its surrounding municipalities), as of 9 September 2020 new restrictions will be placed in these municipalities. The government also requested schools, educational institutions and universities to cancel all social activities.  These rules are scheduled to be in place until 22 September 2020.   http://web.archive.org/web/20200910190710/https://politi.dk/en/coronavirus-in-denmark/new-measures-to-contain-the-further-spread-of-covid-19  http://web.archive.org/web/20200910185555/https://www.thelocal.dk/20200907/denmark-announces-new-restrictions-as-coronavirus-cases-increase

No major change in policy. Venues such as nightclubs and discotheques (that is, venues with few seats, a dance floor etc.) must stay closed until 31 October 2020. The government announced on September 7 2020 that due to an increase in Covid-19 cases in 18 municipalities (including Copenhagen and its surrounding municipalities), as of 9 September 2020, new restrictions will be placed on bars, cafes and restaurants in these municipalities: they are required to close at midnight instead of 2am, as is the current national rule. Restaurants are encouraged to introduce voluntary registration of contact data of guests and hand over the data to the health authorities in connection with the tracking and tracing of outbreaks. It is recommended to limit congestion in shops and to introduce additional disease prevention initiatives in the retail sector (for example limiting the number of customers in a store). These rules are scheduled to be in place until 22 September 2020.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200910190710/https://politi.dk/en/coronavirus-in-denmark/new-measures-to-contain-the-further-spread-of-covid-19  http://web.archive.org/web/20200910185555/https://www.thelocal.dk/20200907/denmark-announces-new-restrictions-as-coronavirus-cases-increase

The government announced on September 7 2020 that due to an increase in Covid-19 cases in 18 municipalities (including Copenhagen and its surrounding municipalities), as of 9 September 2020 new restrictions will be placed in these municipalities. In these municipalities, there is a reduction in the assembly limit from 100 to 50 people. Odense and the Copenhagen area will also be excluded from plans to extend current provisions allowing fans to attend sports matches. These rules are scheduled to be in place until 22 September 2020. The Danish Health Authority will introduce stricter requirements for the number of participants, social distancing, layout etc. in connection with private gatherings. It is also recommended to organise as many activities as possible as outdoor events.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200910190710/https://politi.dk/en/coronavirus-in-denmark/new-measures-to-contain-the-further-spread-of-covid-19  http://web.archive.org/web/20200910185555/https://www.thelocal.dk/20200907/denmark-announces-new-restrictions-as-coronavirus-cases-increase

The government announced on September 7 2020 that due to an increase in Covid-19 cases in 18 municipalities (including Copenhagen and its surrounding municipalities), as of 9 September 2020 new restrictions will be placed in these municipalities. The policy remains unchanged however the Government reminded citizens that they are encouraged to avoid public transport where other means of transport are available – especially during rush hours.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200910190710/https://politi.dk/en/coronavirus-in-denmark/new-measures-to-contain-the-further-spread-of-covid-19  http://web.archive.org/web/20200910185555/https://www.thelocal.dk/20200907/denmark-announces-new-restrictions-as-coronavirus-cases-increase

The government announced on September 7 2020 that due to an increase in Covid-19 cases in 18 municipalities (including Copenhagen and its surrounding municipalities), as of 9 September 2020 new restrictions will be placed in these municipalities. The policy remains unchanged however the Government reminded/reinforced the message that employees at public and private workplaces are recommended to work from home if possible and employees are encouraged not to go to work if they have any covid-19 symptoms.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200910190710/https://politi.dk/en/coronavirus-in-denmark/new-measures-to-contain-the-further-spread-of-covid-19  http://web.archive.org/web/20200910185555/https://www.thelocal.dk/20200907/denmark-announces-new-restrictions-as-coronavirus-cases-increase

The government announced on September 7 2020 that due to an increase in Covid-19 cases in 18 municipalities (including Copenhagen and its surrounding municipalities), as of 9 September 2020 new restrictions will be placed in these municipalities. One of the consequences will be massive information efforts from the Danish Health Authority targeted at citizens in the greater Copenhagen area and the municipality of Odense. Citizens are also encouraged to pay greater attention to the recommendations on social distancing in public spaces, at restaurants and at entertainment and cultural events, including the upcoming  stricter requirements for social distancing at restaurants.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200910190710/https://politi.dk/en/coronavirus-in-denmark/new-measures-to-contain-the-further-spread-of-covid-19  http://web.archive.org/web/20200910185555/https://www.thelocal.dk/20200907/denmark-announces-new-restrictions-as-coronavirus-cases-increase

Government announced additional measures for the greater Copenhagen area and Odense municipality that will be in place at least until October 1st:   - Bars, cafes and restaurants will now have to be closed by 22.00 (instead of midnight as announced earlier in the month and instead of 2 am as is the nation-wide policy).   - Restaurants, bars, cafes and similar establishments will be required to display signs stating the maximum number of people allowed at the premises in order to comply with the floor area requirement  - Greater focus on compliance with the requirement of a minimum distance of one metre (from nose to nose) between guests at restaurants, bars, cafes and similar establishments as well as the implementation of this requirement in the sector partnership guidelines.   - Weddings, confirmations and similar special occasion days that have already been scheduled can be held if it is possible to observe the advice of the Danish Health Authority set out in 'Private events, parties and celebrations during the period of COVID-19' (in Danish), but the event ought to finish by 10.00 pm at the latest.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200917105040/https://politi.dk/en/coronavirus-in-denmark/new-disease-control-measures-targeted-at-nightlife-and-restaurants-in-greater-copenhagen

Government announced on 17 September further restrictions for the greater Copenhagen area and Odense municipality:  - Citizens are urged only to make events, parties and celebrations at private homes for close family members and friends.  -Weddings, confirmations and similar special occasion days that have already been scheduled can be held if it is possible to observe the advice of the Danish Health Authority set out in 'Private events, parties and celebrations during the period of COVID-19' (in Danish), but the event ought to finish by 10.00 pm at the latest.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200917105040/https://politi.dk/en/coronavirus-in-denmark/new-disease-control-measures-targeted-at-nightlife-and-restaurants-in-greater-copenhagen

Government announced that as of September 17 until at least October 1: For the greater Copenhagen area as well as in Odense municipality: Guests at restaurants, bars, cafes and similar establishments are now required to wear a face mask or shield except when seated. This requirement applies to both guests and employees having contact with guests. The same exemptions to the requirement to wear a face mask apply as those applicable in public transport (children etc.). The wearing of face masks remains a requirement on public transport throughout the country.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200917105040/https://politi.dk/en/coronavirus-in-denmark/new-disease-control-measures-targeted-at-nightlife-and-restaurants-in-greater-copenhagen

In the context of rising numbers of Covid-19 in Denmark, the government announced increased restrictions nationally. It is recommended to cancel all social events at day-care facilities, primary and lower secondary schools, after-school facilities, upper secondary schools, institutions of higher education etc. The recommendation also applies to events not organised by the institution or school, such as school parties, birthdays, camps etc., even though the children and young people normally spend the day together. These measures will apply in Denmark until at least 4 October 2020.      http://web.archive.org/web/20200921180900/https://politi.dk/en/-/media/mediefiler/corona/engelsk/outbreak-control-measures.pdf?la=en&hash=E082FB214E3BC7E3F56FD65411BFF68296CC2F23

In the context of rising numbers of Covid-19 in Denmark, the government announced increased restrictions nationally. The opening hours of restaurants, bars, cafes and similar establishments with the required licences will be limited to 10.00 pm.  It is also no longer possible for establishments to stay open from 10.00 pm to 5.00 am to host private parties attended by people largely familiar to each other. Public and private employers are encouraged to ensure that all social events at and in connection with workplaces are cancelled.  These measures will apply in Denmark until at least 4 October 2020.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200921180900/https://politi.dk/en/-/media/mediefiler/corona/engelsk/outbreak-control-measures.pdf?la=en&hash=E082FB214E3BC7E3F56FD65411BFF68296CC2F23

In the context of rising numbers of Covid-19 in Denmark, the government announced increased restrictions nationally. It is recommended to cancel all civic festivals and similar events (such as open-by-night involving retail shops, institutions etc. in the public space). These are events at which many people gather in town, sometimes in combination with business and cultural life, which can be characterised by circumstances, such as the consumption of alcohol involving ‘loss of control’, that increase the risk of non-compliance with the recommendations on social distancing and hand hygiene. The maximum number of people who can gather is reduced from 100 people to 50 people (for all of Denmark) as of 19 September 2020. This is regardless whether it is an outdoor or indoor event. Note that it will still be possible to host and attend  events etc. with up to 500 participants if the participants are mainly seated. However, the exception of allowing more than 500 people to attend Super League football matches or indoor or outdoor sports events will no longer apply (the maximum is now set at 500).  These measures will apply in Denmark until at least 4 October 2020.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200921180900/https://politi.dk/en/-/media/mediefiler/corona/engelsk/outbreak-control-measures.pdf?la=en&hash=E082FB214E3BC7E3F56FD65411BFF68296CC2F23

In the context of rising numbers of Covid-19 in Denmark, the government announced increased restrictions nationally. The maximum number of people who can gather is reduced from 100 people to 50 people (for all of Denmark) as of 19 September 2020. This is regardless whether it is an outdoor or indoor event. Note that it will still be possible to host and attend  events etc. with up to 500 participants if the participants are mainly seated. However, the exception of allowing more than 500 people to attend Super League football matches or indoor or outdoor sports events will no longer apply (the maximum is now set at 500). There is also now a requirement to display signs stating the maximum number of customers, visitors or participants allowed at premises. Owners of restaurants, bars, cafes and similar establishments are encouraged to introduce voluntary registration of the contact data of guests and to hand over the data to the health authorities for the purpose of tracing outbreaks. It is no longer allowed to consume alcohol on coaches and buses operated under the Danish Coach and Bus. Weddings, confirmations and similar special occasion days that have already been scheduled can be held if it is possible to follow the advice of the Danish Health Authority set out in ‘Private events, parties and celebrations during the period of COVID-19’, but the event ought to end at 10.00 pm at the latest. Citizens are recommended to hold other events, parties and celebrations at private homes only for close family members and friends.  These measures will apply in Denmark until at least 4 October 2020.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200921180900/https://politi.dk/en/-/media/mediefiler/corona/engelsk/outbreak-control-measures.pdf?la=en&hash=E082FB214E3BC7E3F56FD65411BFF68296CC2F23

In the context of rising numbers of Covid-19 in Denmark, the government announced increased restrictions nationally. Citizens are encouraged to travel outside rush hours and to walk or take the bike when travelling short distances.  These measures will apply in Denmark until at least 4 October 2020.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200921180900/https://politi.dk/en/-/media/mediefiler/corona/engelsk/outbreak-control-measures.pdf?la=en&hash=E082FB214E3BC7E3F56FD65411BFF68296CC2F23

In the context of rising numbers of Covid-19 in Denmark, the government announced increased restrictions nationally. Public and private employers are encouraged to make sure that employees work from home to the extent possible and appropriate given the nature of the job.  These measures will apply in Denmark until at least 4 October 2020.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200921180900/https://politi.dk/en/-/media/mediefiler/corona/engelsk/outbreak-control-measures.pdf?la=en&hash=E082FB214E3BC7E3F56FD65411BFF68296CC2F23

In the context of rising numbers of Covid-19 in Denmark, the government announced increased restrictions nationally. Guests at restaurants, bars, cafes and similar establishments will be required to wear a face mask or shield except when seated. This requirement applies to both guests and employees having contact with guests.  The requirement applies when guests arrive at restaurants, when they leave the restaurant and when they leave their table, for example to use the bathroom. Face masks must also be used by guests when they go to the bar to order food or drinks, to pay etc. The requirement applies indoors but not outdoors. These measures will apply in Denmark until at least 4 October 2020.   These measures will apply in Denmark until at least 4 October 2020.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200921180900/https://politi.dk/en/-/media/mediefiler/corona/engelsk/outbreak-control-measures.pdf?la=en&hash=E082FB214E3BC7E3F56FD65411BFF68296CC2F23

Movement continues freely within Denmark. Face masks are required on public transport and in taxis across Denmark and the public is asked to avoid travel at peak times.  All public transport in Denmark is undergoing a more stringent cleaning protocol.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200928150225/https://www.visitdenmark.com/denmark/travel-essentials/safe-travel-denmark

Policy remains unchanged. Those living in a 'yellow' country may freely enter Denmark while those in 'orange' or 'red' may not. Which countries in the EU are labelled 'orange' versus 'yellow' changes from week to week depending on the level of covid. Countries outside the EU and the Schengen area as well as the United Kingdom are currently by definition 'banned' countries (orange).  http://web.archive.org/web/20200924160654/https://politi.dk/en/coronavirus-in-denmark/travel-in-or-out-of-denmark/is-my-country-open-or-banned

There have been no recent policy changes regarding the opening of schools. However, new “measures in the area of children and education will enter into force on 29 October and apply until 2 January 2021”, due to the increasing spread of infection in Denmark, which include:  “Pupils and trainees in secondary and adult education must wear bandages when moving around the educational institution. Students and course participants are not required to wear a sanitary napkin when attending classes.  Teachers in secondary and adult education who teach in more than two classes / teams during a day must wear bandages or visors.  Teachers and educators have the right to use visors in day care and primary school if they wish.”  “In addition, it is still recommended to cancel events with accommodation such as colonies, camp schools and study trips.” Source: https://archive.vn/e4ynB  Furthermore, guidance universities, such as Aarhus University, have put in place to ensure social distancing and additional hygiene precautions still current include: “Sanitise your hands whenever you enter a building, and whenever you enter a new room.” “Arrive at the classroom no earlier than ten minutes before your class starts.” “When you use group rooms, study spaces etc…don’t move tables, chair, etc.” Source: https://archive.vn/1Gx3a

Commercial, public, and government services are widely open, though some have restricted capacities to adhere to social distancing policies.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201020110726/https://dk.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/

Venues such as nightclubs remain closed until October 31, 2020. Large gatherings are limited to 100 people and public events limited to 500.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201020110726/https://dk.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/

Venues such as nightclubs remain closed until October 31, 2020. Large gatherings are limited to 100 people and public events limited to 500.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201020110726/https://dk.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/
Is public transportation operating? Yes  Public transport passengers are required to wear face masks or shields.

Travelers from “open countries” – as classified by Denmark – may travel to Greenland if they present a negative COVID-19 test result taken in a Nordic country (Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Finland, Iceland, or the Faroe Islands) no more than five days prior to travel.  Open countries include mostly other Nordic countries and the Schengen Area.  A travel ban remains in place for travelers from other countries – including the United States – unless the traveler has a “worthy” purpose of travel as classified by Denmark; such travelers must quarantine upon arrival.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201020110726/https://dk.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/

Temporary liquidity measures, including postponement of tax payments and government guarantees, will further support activity in Denmark.   The DN announced the launch of an ‘ extraordinary lending facility ’ which will make full-allotment, 1-week, collateralized loans available to banks at -0.5 percent interest rate on March 20. Public transport passengers are required to wear face masks or shields.  Airline passengers must wear surgical face masks from the moment they enter a terminal and while on board a flight until they leave the terminal after their arrival  Danish National Police may fine individuals for violating COVID-19 regulations. The fine for failure to wear a face mask, violating gathering limits, or loitering in areas deemed “hotspots” is 2500 Danish Kroner for a first-time offense and can increase thereafter for repeated violations. Schools have not been closed in general since before the summer vacation. A school can choose to close for a short period due to Covid-19 cases in the school amongst teachers or pupils just to avoid further spreading the virus. On a press meeting on October 23rd the prime minister announced new restriction. As part of her speech she pointed out that it is a priority for the government to keep schools open. https://web.archive.org/web/20201030113153/https://coronasmitte.dk/overblik

On October 23rd the prime minister announced new restrictions. As part of this announcement she said that it is still recommended that employees in public and private companies work from home if it is possible. https://web.archive.org/web/20201030113153/https://coronasmitte.dk/overblik
Before the announcement on October 23rd you were only allowed to be in groups of up to 50 people
Public transportation is still running but you need to wear a mask. https://web.archive.org/web/20201030113153/https://coronasmitte.dk/overblik

At a press conference on October 23rd the prime minister announced new restrictions. At the same time she made it clear that it is a priority for the government to keep the businesses in Denmark running including shops, restaurants etc. No recommendation to stay at home was given and it has also not been the case since before the summer vacation.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201030113153/https://coronasmitte.dk/overblik

Persons resident in countries/regions classified as banned can enter Denmark if they have a worthy purpose. If you arrive from a 'high-risk country' within the EU and the Schengen area as well as the United Kingdom or from at 'banned country' outside the EU or the Schengen area or the United Kingdom, you are required to present proof of a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours before entry. On this page you will find information about rules and required documents.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://um.dk/da/rejse-og-ophold/rejse-til-udlandet/coronavirus/

To avoid people are getting fired it is possible as a company to seek compensation for lost revenue as a consequence of restrictions. A public campaign has been running in Denmark since March 2020. It includes promotion on Social Media with advise from the Health authorities on how to avoid getting Covid-19. A Corona badge has also been offered to all citizens in Denmark - when you wear it you remind other people to keep a safe distance. Posters have been made available in many language for download and print showing an overview of current restrictions, reminding to keep the safe distance, wash your hands etc. There is one site where all the information is being made available for the public: https://web.archive.org/web/20201030113153/https://coronasmitte.dk/overblik

If you have been tested positive for Covid-19 the Health authorities will contact you and support you in making sure all your close connections are being asked to also get a test. https://web.archive.org/web/20201030124918/https://coronasmitte.dk/coronaopsporing

Starting from 23 November 2020, new measures have been implemented to contain the infection in Holstebro and Ringkøbing-Skjern municipalities. This is because a high incidence of infection has been found among people related to mink farms and fur series.    "[R]esidents of the affected municipalities are encouraged to interact with as few people as possible."    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201124080425/https://coronasmitte.dk/anbefalinger-i-holstebro-og-ringkoebing-skjern    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201124073155/https://coronasmitte.dk/overblik

The government continues to implement restrictions that require "partial use of sanitary napkins in educational institutions". The restriction will be applicable from 26 October 2020 to 2 January 2021.    Meanwhile, there are no longer any special, local restrictions in North Jutland. The same restrictions apply as in the rest of Denmark.    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201124073155/https://coronasmitte.dk/overblik

Restaurants, bars, cafes, and all other stores are open, with sanitation and social distancing requirements.     http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201124074034/https://coronasmitte.dk/arkader-butiks-og-storcentre    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201124074044/https://coronasmitte.dk/forretninger-med-taet-kundekontakt    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201101040230/https://coronasmitte.dk/natklubber-vaertshuse-restauranter-spillehaller

The government continues to restrict, but not ban, public events.     "The assembly ban is maintained for a maximum of 10 people. However, certain exceptions apply.  The assembly ban at outdoor funerals and funerals is maintained at a maximum of 50 people."    According to the government's announcement, the limit of 10 people applies from 26 October 2020 until and including 13 December 2020.    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201124073155/https://coronasmitte.dk/overblik  http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201124074446/https://coronasmitte.dk/arrangementer-og-forsamlinger

The government continues to restrict assemblies. With a few exceptions, "[i]t is forbidden to hold or participate in events, events, activities or the like where more than 10 people are present in the same place at the same time. The ban applies both indoors and outdoors and includes both public and private events, events, etc."    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201124074446/https://coronasmitte.dk/arrangementer-og-forsamlinger    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201124073155/https://coronasmitte.dk/overblik
Public transport is open but with mask-wearing and social distancing requirements.    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201124073155/https://coronasmitte.dk/overblik

The government continues to intensify border control. Countries and regions are classified as open, quarantine, or high-risk.     "Persons residing in a country / region that is categorized as open (yellow) may travel into Denmark regardless of purpose."    "Persons residing in a quarantine country (within the EU, Schengen and the United Kingdom) that is not categorized as a high-risk country may travel into Denmark if they have a recognizable purpose for the trip."    "Persons residing in a high-risk country (within the EU, Schengen and the United Kingdom)must enter Denmark with a recognizable purpose, but must also be able to show a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test, which must have been taken a maximum of 72 hours before entry."    "Countries outside the EU, Schengen and the United Kingdom are currently by definition quarantined countries. See exceptions, ie. third countries categorized as open, further down the page...Persons residing in one of these quarantine countries must enter Denmark with a recognizable purpose, but must also be able to show a test on a negative COVID-19 test, which must have been taken a maximum of 72 hours before entry."    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201124082233/https://coronasmitte.dk/rejser-ind-i-danmark/er-mit-land-len-aabent-eller-i-karantaene    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201124073155/https://coronasmitte.dk/overblik

***Recoded from 1G to 2G; as there are hygiene programs and some limitations/guidance on visitors to long-term care facilities, this meets the threshold for a 2G ("Narrow restrictions for isolation, hygiene in LTCFs, some limitations on external visitors and/or restrictions protecting elderly  people at home")      Original coding note:   Compared to previous advice, new guidance 25th November which contains:  Expansion of the National Board of Health's general advice and change in the formulation of the main priorities in the prevention of the spread of infection.  Clarifications regarding sections on the virus' transmission modes and symptoms of COVID-19.  Addition of a section on airways and ventilation.  Sharpened focus on situations where there is no concrete suspicion of infection with a new coronavirus, including a new section on the use of face protection products in common areas in accordance with temporary legal requirements, as well as the use of face protection products in close contact with the citizen in the citizen's home.  Clarifications in relation to the description of visit restrictions, including clarification of resp. The role of the Danish Agency for Patient Safety and the Ministry of Social Affairs and the Interior in this regard.  Addition of sections on resuscitation.  Addition of sections about employees who are at increased risk of a serious course with COVID-19  Clarifications in the section on testing when COVID-19 is not suspected or detected, as well as in the section on organizing testing for detected COVID-19 in the institution.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210115185122/https://www.sst.dk/da/Udgivelser/2020/Vejledning-om-forebyggelse-af-spredning-af-COVID-19-paa-plejecentre-bosteder

Version #7 of the guidelines published (no substantial changes, just clarifications vs. Nov 25 edition):  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111195111/https://www.sst.dk/-/media/Udgivelser/2020/Corona/Genaabning/Plejecentre/Vejledning-om-forebyggelse-af-spredning-af-COVID19-paa-plejecentre.ashx?la=da&hash=0871F5300256F9EEF4844E0E809C78C35ED2E85F

The Danish Prime Minister imposed a partial lockdown in 38 municipalities from December 9 to January 3. School children from 5th grade upwards in the affected municipalities are to be sent home, with classes to take place online. The same restriction will be applied to all adult and further education, including upper secondary schools and universities. Exams will take place, but will be moved online wherever possible. https://archive.vn/W3QVP

The Danish Prime Minister imposed a partial lockdown in 38 municipalities from December 9 to January 3. Restaurants, bars, cafes, gyms, sports centres and swimming pools are to be closed in the affected municipalities. Restaurants and cafes will be allowed to operate takeaway services. Public sector workers not in critical functions will work from home in the affected municipalities. Shops remain open. https://archive.vn/W3QVP

The Danish Prime Minister imposed a partial lockdown in 38 municipalities from December 9 to January 3. Indoor areas at amusement parks, zoos, aquariums and similar types of attractions, as well as at museums, theatres, cinemas and libraries, will also all be closed to the public. https://archive.vn/W3QVP

COVID-19 testing to be stepped up in Greater Copenhagen  Testing in Greater Copenhagen has been stepped up and will be intensified in the  weeks ahead.    Additional mobile testing units will be made available locally to ensure access  to testing for as many people as possible. Based on the spread of infections  and an ongoing dialogue with the authorities of the municipalities comprised  by the measures, the mobile testing units will be deployed in locations with  the greatest need.    The intensified testing scheme comprises all citizens.  Announcements will be made locally as to where and when the new testing  opportunities will be available. People are urged to await such  announcements before booking tests unless the test is booked for other  specific reasons such as mild symptoms and test slots for close contacts.  Further, particular efforts will be targeted at young citizens in Greater  Copenhagen who typically account for the highest infection rates. All young  people aged 15 to 25 in Greater Copenhagen are encouraged to take a test.  Announcements will be made locally as to where and when the testing of  those aged 15 to 25 is carried out.          https://web.archive.org/web/20210106161216/https://coronasmitte.dk/en/-/media/mediefiler/corona/hovedstaden/intensified-efforts-to-curb-the-spread-of-covid19-in-greater-copenhagen.pdf?la=en&hash=A35282D491A09102D5284D586457138D5DA61D3B

According to the official calendar, up to the current date the Danish Health Authority has determined that the target groups for the vaccination programme should be given priority in the following order:  - Residents in nursing homes, etc. & People aged = 65 years who receive both personal care and practical assistance.  - Personnel in healthcare, elderly care and selected parts of the social sector who are at particular risk of infection or who has been identified as performing a critical function in society.  - Selected persons with conditions and diseases that result in a significantly increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19.  - Selected relatives of persons at significantly increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19 or relatives who are indispensable as carers.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130122057/https://www.sst.dk/-/media/Udgivelser/2021/Corona/Vaccination/Kalender/Vaccinationskalender-A4-webtilgaengelig.ashx?la=da&hash=5234BB82243B24FD492FDDAC1388CA9A22BC83D6  https://web.archive.org/web/20210130123050/https://www.sst.dk/en/English/Corona-eng/Vaccination-against-COVID-19/Target-groups  https://web.archive.org/web/20210130123058/https://www.sst.dk/-/media/Udgivelser/2021/Corona/Vaccination/Kalender/Specificeret-vaccinationskalender.ashx?la=da&hash=C2818CB774B7C56FCC64981CD7D6B3752EA026AF      The first approved vaccine against COVID-19 is called Comirnaty® and was developed by the German company BioNTech in collaboration with the American company Pfizer. The deliveries of Comirnaty® that we receive to Denmark are produced in factories in Germany and Belgium.   The second vaccine, which is approved for use in the EU and thus Denmark, has been developed by the American company Moderna. COVID-19 vaccine Moderna® is developed on the same technology as Comirnaty®, and is produced in factories in Switzerland and Spain.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130132848/https://coronasmitte.dk/raad-og-regler/emner/vaccination

Persons aged 12 and over must wear a bandage or visor in the following places:  In public transport, etc., including in trains, buses, taxis, ferries, as well as at station areas and stops, etc.  At restaurants where food, drinks or tobacco are served for consumption at the point of sale.  In the retail trade, including in department stores, grocery stores, department stores, department stores, department stores, bazaars, arcades, places that sell food and beverages that are not consumed at the point of sale (take-away), etc.  In premises where cultural, sports and association activities are carried out, including museums, sports halls, fitness centers, art galleries, venues, libraries, cultural centers, zoos, cinemas, theaters, association rooms, etc.  In rooms where the Danish National Church and denominations outside the Danish National Church carry out activities.  In job centers and in citizen service centers.  At institutions that carry out preparatory education, youth education, Danish education for adult foreigners, etc., adult and continuing education, higher education, Folkeuniversitetet, day colleges, evening schools, music and culture schools, driving schools that carry out theory teaching, and folk high schools, etc.  Public and private hospitals and clinics, clinics, etc. in the practice sector, municipal health services, municipal and private care centers and nursing homes, relief places as well as a number of placements and housing facilities in the social area.  During the conduct of practical driving tests, indicative health driving tests and at final tests in driving when one is in a vehicle with others.    Thus, there is no general requirement to wear a bandage or visor in all rooms to which the public has access.    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201124101122/https://coronasmitte.dk/mundbind-og-visir

Citizens of all countries have been banned from entering Denmark from January 9 until January 18, as part of the country’s efforts to prevent the further spread of the Coronavirus pandemic, precisely due to the new mutation of the virus found in Britain and some other countries.    In addition, Denmark’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs has urged all its citizens to avoid travelling to other countries due to the disease’s rapid spread, SchengenVisaInfo.com reports.    The latest announcement of Denmark’s authorities clarified that the whole world would be “sharpened from being orange to red.”    Denmark’s Foreign Minister Jeppe Kofod has stressed that the new mutations of the Coronavirus pandemic, spread in several other countries pose a significant risk that Denmark’s infection rates may escalate.      “The safety and security of Danes is the government’s priority. We can see the finish line. The vaccine is here. We must not stumble on the run-up stretch. Not least in the light of the new mutations, we will have to – all of us – make an extra effort. And today’s package of travel initiatives is an expression of that,” says Foreign Minister Jeppe Kofod.    Recently Denmark announced plans to impose a digital ‘vaccine passport’ which would permit all vaccinated citizens against COVID-19 disease to travel to countries which oblige citizens to have such a document, in order to be able to enter these countries.    According to the Danish Health Ministry, the ‘vaccine passport will be rolled out in early 2021,” and all those vaccinated would be eligible to obtain the document through Denmark’s public health website.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111123210/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/denmark-temporarily-bans-from-entering-citizens-of-all-countries/    From 5:00 p.m. on 9 January 2021 through 7 February 2021, Denmark has instituted a flight ban on the transport of passengers, including Danish citizens, who are unable to present a negative COVID-19 test taken within 24 hours before departure.   https://archive.vn/eOv2R

The Danish border closure – imposed on March 14 – remains in place for. Only travelers residents who qualify for a travel exception (called a “worthy purpose” by the Danish government) can enter Denmark. Some travel exceptions include having a valid residence permit for Denmark, attending a business meeting, or being the spouse, parent, or child of a Danish citizen or legal resident in Denmark.      To prevent the spreading of the British and South African mutations of COVID-19, the Danish government has imposed a flight ban on transportation of passengers from the entire world who are unable to present a negative COVID-19 test.    The flight ban will enter into force 9 January 2021 at 5pm and last until the end of 28 February 2021. You should be tested if:    -You have symptoms that could be COVID-19  -You are told that you are in close contact with a person who is infected with a new coronavirus  -You are told that you must be tested prior to, for example, hospitalization, treatment or examination  -You are told that you must be tested as part of infection detection in the event of an outbreak, eg in primary schools, in day care institutions, in nursing homes, etc.  -You are told that you are 'another contact', and must be tested as soon as possible, eg via Infection | stop the app   -You go to work    The regions and the government have entered into agreements with private suppliers to conduct free rapid tests for all Danes. A rapid test (also called an antigen test) detects virus proteins in a sample and is taken by a nasal swab. The rapid test is less sensitive than the PCR test and therefore does not provide an equally reliable answer.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130131819/https://coronasmitte.dk/raad-og-regler/emner/test-

If you are infected with COVID-19, you are encouraged to contact the Danish Agency for Patient Safety Corona Detection as soon as possible on tel. 32 32 05 11. In any case, Corona Detection tries to contact the infected person within 24 hours after being notified of a positive test result from the Statens Serum Institut (or private test providers), to offer help in locating and contacting the close contacts who may be infected, and thus can also infect others. The infected person is offered help to call and advise the close contacts. It is voluntary if you want help with this task. As an infected person, you can also be responsible for informing close contacts and referring them. The Danish Agency for Patient Safety contacts citizens both by telephone and letter in e-Boks    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130131217/https://coronasmitte.dk/raad-og-regler/smitteopsporing

However, face mask are not mandatory at bus stops.  At establishments selling food, drinks or tobacco for on-site consumption. Please note that restaurants, bars and similar establishments must stay closed.  In wholesale and retail shops, including durable goods shops, grocery shops, shopping centres, department stores, hypermarkets, bazaars, shopping arcades and establishments selling food or drinks not consumed on-site (takeaway) etc. Please note that durable goods shops, shopping centres, department stores, hypermarkets, shopping arcades and establishments selling food or drinks not consumed on-site must stay closed.  At premises for cultural, sports and club activities, including museums, sports centres, fitness centres, art exhibitions, music venues, libraries, cultural centres, zoos, cinemas, theatres and club premises. Please note that such premises must remain closed to the public. At premises at which the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Denmark or other religious communities perform activities.[ANJ1]   At job centres and citizens service centres.  At day-care facilities, elementary schools and after-school care facilities etc.  At institutions of preparatory education, upper secondary schools, Danish language programmes for adult foreigners etc., adult education and continuing training programmes, institutions of higher education, university extension courses, day folk high schools, evening classes, schools of music and arts, driving schools offering theory training, folk high schools etc.  At public and private hospitals and clinics, with independent therapists, in connection with municipal healthcare services, at municipal and private care homes and assisted living housing, at respite care facilities, at a number of foster care facilities and at institutions for people with mental disorders or special needs in the social care sector.  During practical driving tests, guiding driving tests to assess health issues or final driving tests in vehicles together with other passengers.

Current policy still in effect. However, Authorities in Denmark plan to start gradually easing COVID-19-related international travel and domestic activity restrictions. Starting April 21, the Danish government will begin using a color-coded system for classifying foreign countries as being at one of three risk levels - red, orange, or yellow - based on local infection rates and the presence of variant strains, and will apply international travel restrictions accordingly. Travelers arriving from "yellow" countries or regions will not need to self-isolate upon entry. Those arriving from ''orange'' and "red" areas will need to self-isolate for 10 days upon entry. In addition, business travelers will no longer be required to quarantine. All travelers must still, upon arrival, present a negative result from a COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours prior to travel.  Starting May 1, fully vaccinated citizens and residents of Denmark, as well as tourists from yellow and orange countries, will be able to travel to Denmark without restrictions. In addition, the requirement for a negative Covid-19 test result will change; effective May 1, the test will need to have been taken no more than 48 hours before travel, rather than the current threshold of 24 hours.  Most travel from outside the EEA, with the exception of that from Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, South Korea, and Thailand, will be prohibited. Exemptions are in place for EU nationals or residents and their family members, individuals carrying out essential work, or individuals traveling for urgent reasons.  https://archive.vn/Byc3A

Starting April 21, the Danish government will begin using a color-coded system for classifying foreign countries as being at one of three risk levels - red, orange, or yellow - based on local infection rates and the presence of variant strains, and will apply international travel restrictions accordingly. Travelers arriving from "yellow" countries or regions will not need to self-isolate upon entry. Those arriving from ''orange'' and "red" areas will need to self-isolate for 10 days upon entry. In addition, business travelers will no longer be required to quarantine. All travelers must still, upon arrival, present a negative result from a COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours prior to travel.   Starting May 1, fully vaccinated citizens and residents of Denmark, as well as tourists from yellow and orange countries, will be able to travel to Denmark without restrictions. In addition, the requirement for a negative Covid-19 test result will change; effective May 1, the test will need to have been taken no more than 48 hours before travel, rather than the current threshold of 24 hours.  Most travel from outside the EEA, with the exception of that from Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, South Korea, and Thailand, will be prohibited. Exemptions are in place for EU nationals or residents and their family members, individuals carrying out essential work, or individuals traveling for urgent reasons.    https://archive.vn/EsApp

Both Vaccinated and non-vaccinated travelers from red countries must have a worthy reason (essential travel only) to enter Denmark, present a negative PCR test taken within 72 hours of boarding the aircraft, take a further test on arrival, and self-isolate for 10 days.     https://archive.vn/TcvJT  List of red countries - http://web.archive.org/web/20210713122542/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations/entry-into-denmark/categorization-of-countries     Fully vaccinated travelers from green, yellow, and orange countries can enter Denmark for any reason and without restriction. The vaccine must be approved by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) with the last dose received no fewer than 14 days ago. The traveler must also be habitually resident of an EU or Schengen Area country, an Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) country, or a yellow third country.

In Denmark, a face mask or shield is required at the airport. You are also advised to wear a face mask or shield at test centres or when you visit the hospital.    However, some groups are exempt from the required use of face mask or shield. These include, for instance, children up to the age of 12, people with a decreased level of consciousness, or people with physical or mental impairments that make it impossible for them to remove the face mask or shield themselves. Face masks may be removed if the wearer experience a severe discomfort, such as difficulty breathing.
